chunks.chunk_text: How could you?I know, I know, sorry. I didn't sleep well last night.I'll forgive you this time, but make sure you go to bed early tonight because getting a good night's sleep is incredibly important. For example, did you know that people who get enough sleep live about five years longer than people who don't?Wow, so a good night's sleep can lengthen your life. In this programme, we'll be finding out more about the benefits of sleep and, as usual, learning some useful new vocabulary as well.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Why you need a good nights sleep.json

chunks.chunk_text: First, now that you've woken up, I have a question for you.Do you know how much of the average person's life is spent asleep?Is it A. a half, B. a quarter, or C. a third?I think we spend about a third of our lives sleeping.Okay, well, I'll reveal the correct answer at the end of the programme.The question of why humans sleep is not easy to answer.In terms of evolution, why would it make sense to go unconscious
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Why you need a good nights sleep.json

chunks.chunk_text: every night, leaving yourself vulnerable to danger?It can only mean that the benefits gained from sleep are huge.Here, science journalist Ginny Smith explains some of these benefits to BBC Radio 4 programme Inside Science.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Why you need a good nights sleep.json

chunks.chunk_text: When we sleep, our brains refresh, leaving us feeling rested in the morning.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Why you need a good nights sleep.json

chunks.chunk_text: But what about the other side of the story?What happens when you get too little sleep or none at all?Here's Ginny Smith again talking to BBC Radio 4 programme Inside Science.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Why you need a good nights sleep.json

chunks.chunk_text: Having none or too little of something important
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Why you need a good nights sleep.json

chunks.chunk_text: is known as deprivation.Sleep deprivation is stressful for the body, so stressful that it activates a fight or flight response, changes in the human body in response to a life-threatening situation, which make us either stay and fight the threat or run away from it.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Why you need a good nights sleep.json

chunks.chunk_text: Sleep has these knock-on effects.It causes other things to happen, but not directly.Yes, you asked me how much of the average person's life is spent asleep, and I said it was about a third.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Why you need a good nights sleep.json

chunks.chunk_text: The average person will sleep for 229,961 hours in their lifetime, or around one third of their life.OK, let's recap the vocabulary we've learned, starting with the phrases catch 40 winks, get some shut-eye, doze and take a nap, all of which mean to sleep.When someone takes in information, they understand it.If you have a problem and you sleep on it, you delay making a decision until you've had time to think.
chunks.original_filename: RSS_262026947_podcast_1304_Why you need a good nights sleep.json

chunks.chunk_text: Deprivation is an absence or too little of something important, such as food or sleep.The fight or flight response describes changes in the human body in response to a dangerous situation, which make us either stay and fight the threat or run away from it.And finally, if something has a knock-on effect, it causes other results indirectly.Once again, our six minutes are up, but remember to join us again next time for more trending topics
